pyndigo.driver module

This module contain the basic classes upon which INDIGO drivers (and agents) are built. A driver should extend StandardDriverDevice or even PyndigoDriverDevice.

Classes

PyndigoDriverDevice

Base class for a driver device. This class allows the allocation of properties and their handlers.

StandardDriverDevice

A PyndigoDriverDevice that includes the standard CONNECTION property and its handler.

PyndigoDriver

The main class that allows the creation of Drivers for one or more Devices.

class pyndigo.driver.PyndigoDriverDevice(driver: PyndigoDriver, name: str)[source]

Bases: object

This class can be extended in order to develop a Device that can be used in a Driver. It provides the basic functionality to add properties and handlers for them. Take into account that for most of the Devices it is usually better to extend StandardDriverDevice which already implements the standard CONNECTION property.

To add properties you should use the methods:

  • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_text_property(...)

  • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_number_property(...)

  • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_switch_property(...)

  • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_light_property(...)

  • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_blob_property(...)

In addition you can add/remove handlers that listen to property changes from the Clients using the methods:

  • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_property_listener(...)

  • PyndigoDriverDevice.remove_property_listener(...)

__init__(driver: PyndigoDriver, name: str)[source]

Constructs a new PyndigoDriverDevice. This constructor should not be directly used as Devices are supposed to extend this class.

Parameters:

  • driver (PyndigoDriver) – The Driver in which the Device is integrated

  • name (str) – A name for the device.

add_property_listener(prop: pyndigo.common.PyndigoProperty | str, func: Callable[[PyndigoProperty, list[dict]], None]) → None[source]

Adds a method of the class to be a listener when a Client asks for changes in a particular property.

Parameters:

  • property (PyndigoProperty | str) – The Property (or its name) to listen for Client changes on it.

  • func (Callable[[PyndigoProperty, list[dict]], None]) – The method to be called when a Client ask for changes in the property.

remove_property_listener(prop: pyndigo.common.PyndigoProperty | str) → None[source]

Removes the listener associated to a Property.

Parameters:

prop (PyndigoProperty | str) – The Property (or its name) to remove its listener.

add_text_property(name: str, state: str, perm: str, label: str = '', group: str = '', timeout=0, timestamp: str = None, message: str = None) → PyndigoProperty[source]

Creates and adds a Text Property to the Device.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the Property.

  • state (str) – Initial state of the Property. That is, one of STATE_OK, STATE_BUSY, STATE_ALERT or STATE_IDLE.

  • perm (str) – The permissions for the Property. That is, one of pyndigo.common.PERM_RW, pyndigo.common.PERM_RO or pyndigo.common.PERM_WO.

  • label (str, optional) – A label for the Property, typically used in GUIs, by default “”.

  • group (str, optional) – The group of the Property, tyically used to group properties in GUIs, by default “”.

  • timeout (int, optional) – Timeout for the Property, by default 0

  • timestamp (str, optional) – Timestamp for the Property, by default None

  • message (str, optional) – A message about the Property, by default None

Returns:

The created and added Text Property.

Return type:

PyndigoProperty

add_switch_property(name: str, state: str, perm: str, rule: str, label: str = '', group: str = '', timeout=0, timestamp: str = None, message: str = None) → PyndigoProperty[source]

Creates and adds a Switch Property to the Device.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Name of the Property.

  • state (str) – Initial state of the Property. That is, one of STATE_OK, STATE_BUSY, STATE_ALERT or STATE_IDLE.

  • perm (str) – The permissions for the Property. That is, one of pyndigo.common.PERM_RW, pyndigo.common.PERM_RO or pyndigo.common.PERM_WO.

  • rule (str) – The rule of the switch property. That is, one of pyndigo.common.RULE_ONEOFMANY, pyndigo.common.RULE_ATMOSTONE, pyndigo.common.RULE_ANYOFMANY.

  • label (str, optional) – A label for the Property, typically used in GUIs, by default “”.

  • group (str, optional) – The group of the Property, tyically used to group properties in GUIs, by default “”.

  • timeout (int, optional) – Timeout for the Property, by default 0

  • timestamp (str, optional) – Timestamp for the Property, by default None

  • message (str, optional) – A message about the Property, by default None

Returns:

The created and added Switch Property.

Return type:

PyndigoProperty

Return type:

PyndigoProperty

set_value(prop: str, item_name: str, value: str | int) → PyndigoProperty[source]

Sets a value for an Item of a Property of the Device. DOES NOT notify the clients of the change. If you want to notify the clients you should then call send_property_update.

Parameters:

  • prop (str) – The name of the Property to update an Item.

  • item_name (str) – The name of the item to set its value.

  • value (str | int) – The new value of the item

Returns:

The updated Property. None if there was no Property with that name in the Device.

Return type:

PyndigoProperty

set_values(prop: str, item_names_values: list[tuple[str, str | int]]) → PyndigoProperty[source]

Sets the values of several Items of a Property of the Device. DOES NOT notify the clients of the change. If you want to notify the clients you should then call send_property_update.

This is a shorthand for multiple consecutive send_value calls.

Parameters:

  • prop (str) – The name of the Property to update some of its Items.

  • item_names_values (list[tuple[str, str | int]]) – A list of pairs in the form (nameOfItem, valueOfItem).

Returns:

The updated Property. None if there was no Property with that name in the Device.

Return type:

PyndigoProperty

get_value(prop: str, item_name: str) → str | int[source]

Gets the value for an Item of a Property of the Device. Its a shorthand for code like: device.get_property(property_name).get_item(item_name).get_value()

Parameters:

  • prop (str) – The name of the Property of the Device to get one of its items value.

  • item_name (str) – The name of the Item to get its value.

Returns:

The value of the Item. None if there is no such Property or Item in the Device.

Return type:

str | int

set_alert(prop: str) → PyndigoProperty[source]

Sets the State of the Property as STATE_ALERT. DOES NOT notify the clients of the change. If you want to notify the clients you should then call send_property_update.

Parameters:

prop (str) – The name of the Property of the Device.

Returns:

The Property with its state set as STATE_ALERT.

Return type:

PyndigoProperty

send_property_update(prop: str) → None[source]

Sends the message to the clients that a Property has been updated.

Parameters:

prop (str) – The name of the Property that has been updated.

client_asks_for_change(prop: PyndigoProperty, items: dict[str, dict])[source]

This method is called when a client asks for a change in a particular Property. Typically overriden by subclasses to listen for Property changes if not using explicit listeners. See PyndigoDriverDevice.add_property_listener and PyndigoDriverDevice.remove_property_listener

Parameters:

  • prop (PyndigoProperty) – The Property to which a client has asked for changes.

  • items (dict[dict]) – A dictionary of the updates for each Item that was asked for change by the client. The key is the name of the Item. The value is a dictionary with a "value" key that represents the value that the client has asked for in the Item. If the property if a BLOB one, it may also contain a "size", "format" and "url" keys.

class pyndigo.driver.StandardDriverDevice(driver: PyndigoDriver, name: str)[source]

Bases: PyndigoDriverDevice

This class can be extended in order to develop a Device that can be used in a Driver. It adds the standard CONNECTION property that is handled by the client_ask_connect and client_ask_disconnect methods.

__init__(driver: PyndigoDriver, name: str)[source]

Constructs a new StandardDriverDevice. This constructor should not be directly used as Devices are supposed to extend this class.

Parameters:

  • driver (PyndigoDriver) – The Driver in which the Device is integrated

  • name (str) – A name for the device.

client_ask_connect() → None[source]

This method will be called when a client changes the CONNECTION property to CONNECTED. Usually the CONNECTION property State should be changed to STATE_BUSY (and updated to the client), the driver should do its connection logic and then change the state of the CONNECTION to STATE_OK.

Usually implemented by subclasses.

client_ask_disconnect() → None[source]

This method will be called when a client changes the CONNECTION property to DISCONNECTED. Usually the CONNECTION property State should be changed to STATE_BUSY (and updated to the client), the driver should do its disconnection logic and then change the state of the CONNECTION to STATE_OK.

Usually implemented by subclasses.

class pyndigo.driver.PyndigoDriver(name: str)[source]

Bases: object

This class is instantiated in order to create Drivers for one or more Devices.

The main logic to control de Devices should be done extending the classes StandardDriverDevice or PyndigoDriverDevice.

The usual sequence to use this class is:

  1. Create a PyndigoDriver

  2. Create PyndigoDriverDevice (one or more)

  3. Call the read method which starts the routine of reading / writing from / to the clients.

For example:

dr = PyndigoDriver("My driver")
MiOwnDevice(dr)
MiOtherDevice(dr)
dr.read()
__init__(name: str)[source]

Creates a Driver.

Parameters:

name (str) – The name of the Driver

get_driver_devices() → dict[str, pyndigo.driver.PyndigoDriverDevice][source]

Gets all the Devices in the Driver

Returns:

A dictionary with all the Devices in the Driver. The key is the name of the Device and the value is the device itself.

Return type:

dict[str, PyndigoDriverDevice]

get_driver_device(device_name: str) → PyndigoDriverDevice[source]

Gets a Device of the Driver by its name.

Parameters:

device_name (str) – The name of the desired Device.

Returns:

The desired Device. None if there is no Device with the provided name in the Driver.

Return type:

PyndigoDriverDevice

read() → None[source]

Main logic of the driver. It reads from standard input the messages from the Clients (probably through a Server) and process the messages calling listeners in the Devices.

It should be called once the initialization of the Driver is done. It blocks the execution thread (which is the normal behaviour for a Driver.

send_property_definition(prop: PyndigoProperty) → None[source]

Sends to the Clients the definition of a Property. Should be called by the Devices once a new Property is added (only once and not necessary at the initilization of the Devices).

Parameters:

prop (PyndigoProperty) – The Property that has to be sent to the Clients.

send_property_update(prop: PyndigoProperty, msg: str = None) → None[source]

Sends to the Clients an updated Property. Should be called by the Devices once a Property value or State has been changed.

Parameters:

  • prop (PyndigoProperty) – The Property whose updated has to be sent to the Clients.

  • msg (str, optional) – A message to be sent along with the update, by default None
